newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul prepares to welcome defector, aid to North.
newsitem.headline: Seoul prepares to welcome defector, aid to North.

text.p: South Korea put the finishing touches on Saturday to a plan for ending a 68-day odyssey by the highest-ranking North Korean official to flee the impoverished nation.

A Seoul government official told Reuters that Hwang Jang-yop, who defected in Beijing on February 12 and is now taking refuge in the Philippines, would be flown to South Korea on Sunday on a special plane.

Another government official said Seoul had decided to offer about $10 million in fresh food aid to the famine-threatened North but the exact amount would depend on Pyongyang' response to a peace proposal
"The amount could be reduced by a couple of million dollars if we are not happy with the North's response," he said.

The new aid through the World Food Programme is in addition to $6 million Seoul had already donated to the U.N. body before it raised an aid appeal to $95.5 million from an earlier $41.6 million. Washington has pledged $25 million to the programme.
Some Western officials say Hwang could give an insight into the state of Pyongyang's government and military as it grapples with an economic catastrophe.
His scheduled arrival in Seoul comes at a sensitive time as the United States and South Korea try to persuade Pyongyang to join landmark four-nation peace talks, which include China.
In a separate development, North Korea on Saturday agreed to hold Red Cross talks with South Korea on food aid.

The South Korean Red Cross said its North Korean counterpart accepted a proposal for "speedy and smooth" delivery of food and other relief materials. The North suggested their first meeting take place in Beijing on May 3.
The South Korean Red Cross on Friday called for a meeting as soon as possible at the Korean border village of Panmunjom and it has not yet agreed to Beijing as the venue.

The South Korean Red Cross has made 14 relief shipments since November 1996 to North Korea. Religious and other civic groups in South Korea have pledged to raise about $20 million to ship 110,000 tonnes of corn to the communist state.
In New York, the United States and the two Koreas are due to resume discussions later on Saturday, delayed from Friday at North Korea's request.

The meeting was arranged to hear Pyongyang's formal response to a year-old U.S.-South Korean proposal for peace talks that would finally close the books on the 1950-53 Korean War by replacing the armistice with a peace treaty.
Delegates from the three nations held an inconclusive meeting on Wednesday. U.S. and South Korean officials remained optimistic the North would respond positively to the talks.
U.S. officials said privately Pyongyang essentially accepted the peace talks proposal on Wednesday but then tied its acceptance to demands for additional food assistance.
Both Washington and South Korea maintain large-scale aid can be discussed once Pyongyang sits at the peace table.
Seoul officials said Hwang's departure from the Philippines would not be affected by the outcome of the New York meeting.
"You can expect an announcement tomorrow morning after Hwang Jang-yop leaves the Philippines," an official said. "There will, of course, be another announcement after he arrives in our country."

Hwang was spirited to a hideout in the Philippines on March 18 after arriving in South Korea's consulate in Beijing on February 12. His exact whereabouts in the Philippines have remained a well-kept secret.
Hwang, chief architect of the North's governing ideology of "juche", a creed of self-reliance, is expected to issue a statement on his arrival in the South, Seoul officials said.
